Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Understanding of Ion Intercalation Processes in Rechargeable Aluminum-Carbon Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the great challenges facing the Nation is to develop novel technologies that transform how renewable sourced energy can be sustainably and economically stored on a massive scale. Rechargeable batteries, which store energy electrochemically, have revolutionized consumer electronics. For greater scale applications including electric vehicles and grid-scale storage of renewable energy sources, substantial improvements are required for the performance properties of energy density, lifetime, and cost. Aluminum metal is a potentially ideal battery electrode material because it is earth abundant, non-flammable, non-toxic, low cost, and can store more charge per unit volume than other common metals. Recently, research on rechargeable batteries composed of aluminum metal and carbon electrodes has been published. However, mechanistic aspects of how the battery stores charge within the carbon electrodes are poorly understood. This project seeks to elucidate the fundamental processes underpinning how the carbon electrodes store and release ions and energy, particularly at the molecular level. These scientific insights will be used to design and synthesize novel carbon electrodes that will result in rechargeable aluminum-carbon batteries with improved energy storage properties. For educational outreach, high school and undergraduate students will collaborate with university researchers and receive advanced training on electrochemical systems. This research will be disseminated to a broader audience by high school demonstrations and on the City University of New York (CUNY) TV station, which is publically broadcast across New York City.

The overarching objectives of this project are to understand ion intercalation processes in rechargeable aluminum-carbon batteries at the molecular level, and to use these insights to design new carbon electrode structures with improved energy storage properties. Aluminum-graphite batteries using ionic liquid electrolytes will first be studied to reveal insights into the chemical and structural changes that occur within the battery electrolyte and electrode materials as a function of state-of-charge and cycle number. The molecular-level environments, ion speciation and dynamics, and structures of intercalated carbon electrodes will be characterized by multi-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), electron microscopy, and other techniques. These properties will be correlated with bulk electrochemical properties and device performance, yielding new multi-scale understanding. Alternative non-corrosive electrolyte systems will be investigated, which will enable studies of how mixtures of different ionic and solvent species participate and/or affect the intercalation processes. Lastly, novel carbon electrodes based on graphene and carbon nanotubes will be synthesized and tested in aluminum-carbon batteries. In particular, the role of local carbon structures and the effects of disorder on bulk electrochemical properties will be understood and controlled to yield improved electrode materials. Answers to the fundamental scientific questions posed in this work will enable researchers to better understand whether aluminum-carbon batteries could become practical energy storage systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rechargeable aluminum-graphite batteries are an emerging electrochemical energy storage technology with great promise: aluminum and graphite are both earth abundant, low cost, and inherently safe electrode materials, while they have been shown to charge and discharge at ultra-fast rates. Aluminum-graphite batteries store electrical charge when chloroaluminate anions, present in the liquid electrolyte, electrochemically insert (charge) and disinsert (discharge) between graphite layers. However, there are many fundamental scientific questions regarding how they storage charge, including the molecular-level details of how they function, the optimal graphite structure, and why they can charge and discharge so quickly. 

First, graphite structure-property relationships were elucidated by studying the electrochemical properties of different pristine graphites: natural, synthetic, and pyrolytic graphites. Natural graphite stored the most charge, synthetic graphite was the fastest but the least reversible, while pyrolytic graphite stored the least amount of charge but was the most reversible. Such differences were rationalized by comparing details of their structures. Electrochemical analyses revealed that the ions can insert into the graphite very quickly, depending on the graphite structure and voltage. These results were surprising, as chloroaluminate anions are larger and bulkier molecules compared to smaller ions that can move more quickly, such as lithium cations. The average chemical compositions of graphite electrodes fully intercalated (inserted) with chloroaluminate anions were compared to calculations using a hard-sphere model, yielding estimates into the maximum theoretical charge storage possible and how the anions form ordered "stages" in the graphite layers. 

Subsequently, graphite electrodes electrochemically intercalated with chloroaluminate anions were studied at a molecular level using solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT) quantum chemical calculations.  NMR revealed that the intercalated chloroaluminate anions exist in a broad range of local environments, contrasting with the highly ordered and uniform structures often presented in the literature. The results establish that the high extents of local disorder are largely due to chloroaluminate AlCl4- anions in different molecular geometries. Interestingly, these geometries include highly distorted, planar-like configurations of AlCl4- at lower cell voltages, when the graphite layers have not yet expanded. This result suggests that chloroaluminate anions can insert even before the graphite layers fully expand to form ordered stages, which could be one contributing factor to their fast rate performance. 

Next, the graphite structure was modified as a means to further study the fast ionic transport that contributes to the high-rate capabilities of rechargeable aluminum-graphite batteries. Two model structures were studied: pristine graphite as well as graphite wherein the layers had been exfoliated by a mild ultrasonic treatment. Using advanced electrochemical measurements and analyses, we disentangled quantitatively the overall charge mechanisms into (i) diffusion-limited Faradaic contributions, where "Faradaic" indicates that the electrochemical reaction involves electron charge transfer and "diffusion-limited" means that the microscopic movements of the ions are the rate-limiting step, (ii) non-diffusion-limited Faradaic contributions, also known as "pseudocapacitive," where ion movements do not limit the rate of electrochemical reaction, and (ii) capacitive contributions, which involve the separation of charge. The results revealed that graphite electrodes exhibited significant pseudocapacitive contributions over common experimental conditions, consistent with their fast rate performance, while exfoliation increased pseudocapacitive charge storage at higher voltages and faster charging/discharging rates. It was shown that the rate of ion transport in the liquid electrolyte phase within the porous graphite electrode plays an important role in how fast the battery can charge. This phenomenon is different compared to many other common battery chemistries, wherein the charge/discharge rate is controlled by how fast the ions can move inside the solid electrode material. Exfoliation is shown to be a low-cost, scalable method that reduces the tortuosity of the graphite electrode, thereby increasing the efficiency of how the ions move through the porous electrode structure.

This project has contributed significantly to the development of a technical workforce in the energy sector, including those from backgrounds traditionally underrepresented in STEM. One Ph.D. student, five undergraduate students, and one high school student have been trained in interdisciplinary scientific research encompassing chemical engineering, electrochemistry, physical chemistry, and materials science. Two students have pursued additional education in science and engineering, while five students have secured technical jobs in industry. The Ph.D. student received a prestigious fellowship from the U.S. Department of Energy's (DOE's) Office of Science Graduate Student Research (SCGSR) Program, while the high school student was a national finalist (top 300) in the 79th Regeneron Science Talent Search; both awards were associated with this NSF-funded research. 

Lastly, this research has revealed new scientific insights that are expected to accelerate the technological development of low-cost, safe, earth-abundant rechargeable aluminum-graphite batteries. While development of this technology is still in the laboratory phase, it has the potential to be developed in the future as a next-generation electrochemical energy storage technology.
